reviewText:
When reading reviews prior to playing a game yourself, it can be easy to forget that people are often idiots when it comes to writing reviews.

Quite often, despite 100+ hours of gameplay, you'll have someone trashing out a game for one reason or another - however if they bothered to invest that amount of time, then obviously there's something about the game they quite enjoy.

Space Run is by no means perfect - but what game is? If you enjoy TD games then ~$4 while this is on sale is an absolute steal. You will be surprised by the production value of the game vs. the price tag.

I also recommend Space Run as it attempts to do something different which works.

7/10

Only Played the first 4 missions and already im practically in love with this game. it takes strategy when placing things. at first it's either gain speed or gain firepower. i can only imagine how the later stages play out, for a tower defense it does have an interesting story with interesting characters with good dialog and for me getting it for $3.74 is a pretty good deal and I'd highly recommend you reading this buy this game and try it out.

Space Run is the best and the most innovative tower defense game I've ever played. Superb level design, fun challenges, and great sense of humor is what you are going to get from this joint. If I had to point out one problem about this game it would be that some structures are not useful until the very last stage of the game. Most of the time I could beat the game with a few combos. There is space for improvement on the tower design part. Still I think this game is at least way superior than Kingdom Rush. 9/10.

Great space-age strategy game. Kinda sucks that there isn't a multiplayer option; the game could be ADDICTIVE if it were implemented. Of course, the style of play relies on a pre-generated map of obstacles that you can adjust to by replaying the level many times, so a multiplayer mode may not be possible.
All in all, this is a pretty decent game. I actually got it as part of an offer with my AMD graphics card. The options I had seemed lackluster, but this turned out to be quite a good game. Too bad I already played it through.

For some reason, I seem to catch my dad playing this on my computer every other week. If the game wasn't so short, I would tell him to just buy it for himself.
awesome game
Really nice take on genre

Very nice take on the tower defense genre- in some ways it reverses the standards to create a somewhat unique concept.

As Buck Mann, *the* space truckiest space trucker, it's your job to deliver cargo no matter what. You do it fast and you do it safe and that's why people hire you despite your despicable hat. There is a bit of a story (which I haven't played through fully yet), but it's forgettable. Lots of people hire you, there's some crossing of purposes and shady space pirates, but that's about it. It's all just cut-scenes and dialog portraits but, as a nice surprise, it's all fully voiced. And the voice acting is not bad either. In fact it's quite good. All characters have a distinct personality, from rough-and-ready Buck Mann to salty (space) sea-dog Brown Beard. It's fun listening to their banter.

But you don't play these games for their plot. This is tower defense, only this time, you... well... instead of having a level where enemies walk down paths and you plop down towers, the level flies through space. No wait, that really is how things are.

Each level is a straigh path, and you have a spacecraft made of connected cells. Everything from cargo to engines to weapons is placed on these cells. As you travel across your route obstacled and enemies fly in from all directions, and it's your task to build up your defenses in such a way that you can take out those pesky asteroids, pirates, and whatnot, earning credits (hexnuts, in this case, don't ask!) to build more stuff. All your constructions can be upgraded in several ways; allowing you to rotate guns on the fly, increase the radius of shields, or have destroyed cells drop some credits to allow faster rebuilding. It's all somewhat generic but also never shallow- you get what you expect and it works all pretty well, especially with the constant lack of space on your craft (because you can't build new cells, ever). More firepower or more speed? Some shields to protect your cargo, or an additional thruster? It's often a frenetic balancing act.

With the solid mechanics in place, Space Run also goes out of the way to look really nice. There's a certain LEGO flair to everything and while the game never explodes with effects it just looks confidently charming without taxing the hardware.

There's a nice amount of missions and three difficulty settings- you can alway return to a mission with new upgrades to beat your score, which is also used to unlock new stuff. The game checks for delivered cargo AND your delivery time, and some missions you'll have to play again with better thrusters or other upgrades to earn the maximum possible score.

All in all, for a tower defense fan, this is an easy recommendadion just to see a new take on the genre- just get it and you'll have some good fun..
Even if you're just partial to some oddball space scenario where you blow up stuff, you may get some mileage out of Space Run- give it a try while it is on a sale (I got it on a recent 75% sale and those 4 euros were well spent).

There are some things I would've liked to be included- a pause button and a zoom, for example, but what you get is all solid, proud, and true to the genre.

reviewText: (my first ever review) I highly recommend this game to any strategy fan.  There's enough variety to keep you enthralled for a few hours, lots of action during later missions so quick thinking and quick responses are essential.  Thoughtful placement of cargo at the start of later missions is critical, so it's a bit like a puzzle game as well.  I've had lots of fun with this one and it was well worth the money so I just had to write a review.

Great game, fun to play and kept me coming back to get better scores or buy more upgrades.

Pros

Cons

This game is great, makes you rethink some of the typical strategies in tower defence games. My only real complaint is that its too short...if they added a few game modes or some additional levels via DLC this game would be even better. Still you do get a decent play through time (i played it for about 20 hours before i unlocked almost everything). Going back and replaying stages with different equipment once its unlocked does increase the replay value but it still needs more for me to do.

All in all I recommend the game...its fairly short, but its also fairly cheap too. Bottom line..if they released a sequel..i would buy it, same goes for DLC.

Edit*

After some time away from the game, i have started it up again to try to best my previous scores. It does have some replayability as i mentioned above but this game badly needs some DLC to add some more meat to it...all in all my only complaint is i still  want more!!!
If you do not pay any attention to the writing, voice acting, or characters, this is actually a fun little game.

I really like this game. It is an interesting take on tower defense but it's even more fun to upgrade a spaceship than to just put towers around a map.

The only thing that seems to need work is the progression. Everything is fun and smooth until 53 stars. (Level 53?) It's not the end yet,  but it's now almost impossible to get new stars. Furthermore, the currency is so worthless at this point that it's really hard to buy further upgrades. How about allowing unused nuts to become currency at the end of each map? I don't want to keep running the same maps grinding out money to update something insignificant. Without doing so, you'll never get to the true upgrades that will help you progress.

Games don't have to last forever. Artificially preventing me from completing a game by forcing me to grind is not the same as actually building in more hours worth of content. I stopped playing Final Fantasy for just this reason. Let's not pretend this is a good idea.

The game is fun and worth the money I paid for it. The only thing lacking is my sense of accomplishment from finishing the game. Unfortunately, at this point I'm tired of running the same maps over and over....

It was fun in the beginning, but at some point the difficulty ramps up quite high. Eventually I was advancing only through torturous trial and error, memorizing the incoming vectors of every ship and asteroid (which never change btw) and optimizing construction accordingly. Maybe that's what some people want, but not me. Oh well, it was fun while it lasted I guess.\n\nTentative recommendation, if you want a space-y twist on a tower defense game.

Space Run is a rolling tower defense where you build on a hex based ship with all the usual turrets that you could expect from any TD.

Enemies and also environmental hazards periodically spawn from any direction (scripted) rather than just an awkward path, which means for some of the tougher levels you actually need to try a few times to get the feel of the rapidly changing field.

At times the action can be frantic as you balance the ships outgoing damage and weapon facings while managing the repairs and protection of your sometimes volatile cargo. All this while trying to maintain velocity to hit the high scores and get extra credit for upgrades.

The upgrade system itself is simple and clear with early option still retaining value in the later missions as the more powerful items usually come at a balancing cost or are more specialized.

Honestly I wouldn't change a thing in this game worth the price of admission even at twice the price.

In space run you are given the task of making it from point A to point B, you fly a space ship holding valuable cargo and it must make its way to base via a route as quick as possible, this basicly means youre flying in the face of danger. Worry not, for your tools against imminent doom are plentiful. As you fly, topspeed, you must find a balance betwen speed, survival and offence using resources gained in the heat of battle to build extra engines, turrets and other spaceship goodies.

The game has the basic addictive tenets of most tower defense games, but suffers slightly less replayability since its basic premise is to complete a combative time-trial, meaning that there is no endless mode" as is for most tower defense games

Smart tower defense game. The hex-building mechanics keep each mission feeling fresh and every cargo you have to haul has its own unique challenges (eg. they take up awkward amounts of hexes and drain ship power etc). There is a lot you are asked to manage somewhat frantically - collected resources (which requires weapons, which you also need for defense), the speed of your ship, and how your components fit and work together. There is even a witty android co-pilot to wisecrack at your progress.\n\nThere is definitely enough here that any tower defense fan will love and find very fresh. This is a must buy if you enjoyed Defense Grid or pretty much any other tower defense game.

Space Run is the newest tower-defense-concept. You dont have Enemies, which go trough a maze or a path. Instead you build a Spaceship which you have defend.

Since the release they improved the controls (tower reposition). Some Release-Reviews may be outdated. Some other guys complained about the fact that the game can be hectic sometimes. Don´t except pause or checkpoints functions. Because one mission takes between 5 and 15 minutes I don´t think checkpoints are necessary.

The Game offers:
- 30 missions
- defending a space ship with shields, generators, turrets and engines
- destroying gigantic asteroids, civil ships, pirat ships
- destroying pirat bosses
- optional targets (max. 5 stars(fame/renown/reputation points) per mission rewarding a perfekt delivery)
- hectic gameplay in advanced missions
- repostion the turrets and use special abilities of other towers, once they are unlocked
- english dubbed dialogues, various subtitle-languages
- at least 9h play time. The game took me 15h to complete without collecting 150 stars/fame

What I like about the game
- hectic / fast paced strategy in advanced missions. You have some time to think, but mircomanagment is important.
- new way of tower defense
- ease to control with mouse. Optional Hotkeys are available

I don´t like about the game:
- surprising long loading screen (30s-50s) if you launch the game

Have you ever played the tabletop game 'Galaxy Trucker'? If yes, imagine a single-player version of it, mixed with Real-Time Tower Defense.

If you haven't, well, a few more words.
Personally, I'm not a fan of regular tower defense games, but generally the more irregular ones (e.g. Dungeon Defenders) do strike a chord for me. So, along comes Space Run. I bought it more on a whim, because it reminded me of the above mentioned tabletop game, which I immensely enjoy.

So, what is it with this game?

Essentially, you're a guy tasked to ship stuff from A to B, as fast as possible, and hopefully without losing any of the stuff you're supposed to ship. To fulfill this task you get an empty ship made from hex-tiles which you can then populate with weapons, defenses, and of course the cargo you're supposed to transport.
However, you only place the cargo (and generally a single cheap engine) at the beginning of the round. The rest you have to build, rebuild and manage when and as the situation demands with funds you gain during the rounds from destroying random asteroids, enemies and such. The placement of your constructions is a key feature, e.g. engines can only be built on tiles that face space behind the ship, while turrets can be placed in any direction at the edge of your ship, but then can only fire in the directions they can reach. So you'll soon find that one of the most important creeds of your game is going to be 'Location, Location, Location'.

While the first levels (imo) were starting out pretty easy, the latter ones do have a tendency to become rather hectic and challenging, especially when you have to start to compromise (or rather, optimize) wether you need more space for engines to meet a higher quality deadline or rather place another turret to prevent your other engines from getting wrecked by enemy fire.

Inbetween rounds you have then the Engineering section where you can upgrade the constructions you already have or unlock new ones from the money that you received during your missions. You can repeat your missions as often as you like, so running your favorite runs multiple times to gather up some money is not a bad idea, especially since getting the best ratings in the later levels really requires the good stuff, in addition to your knowledge how to best use what in which situation. All constructions have 3 upgrade, 2 of which are active abilities, that all differ immensely (at least in the weapon section), and one passive.

The story" of the game is pretty weak and is basically nothing much more than an explanation of 'You're a guy shipping stuff from A to B

reviewText: 9/10. It solidly satisfies the tower defense itch while giving you access to improvements and encouraging ship-to-ship combat. The object of this game is to get your cargo to the destination in tact as quickly as possible. So it is fairly normal to pull into the dock with a completely wrecked, smoldering ship that only contains your cargo and some overheated engines.
Cool strategy/Turret defence game. Easy at first if you get the basics, but it gets harder fast. my expectations were meet 100 %!\n\nBUY IT & TRY IT!!!
A fresh spin on the good old TD mechanics, although it's not as hard as people make it up to be.\n8.5/10 for what it is.

A unique game worthy of a second playthrough (to see if you can get 5 stars every time without repeating missions for cash). It is complex enough to have strategic depth, but still elegant and just the right difficulty for an intelligent, quick-thinking gamer (admittedly with a few spikes).

Its only mechanical flaw is that you will need a high APM to micromanage optimally, especially since they made the silly decision to make you pick up resources manually. Some people will wish the game had a way to slow or stop time without restrictions.

The story has a few funny moments, but it has way more cring-worthy ones, and sometimes they won't let you skip cutscenes (you can skip the dialogue but the visual doesn't speed up if you're in a mission).

Tower Offense in a way. You have a ship (shape changes each mission) that flys from left to right, and is made of hexagons you can mount various objects. Some Weapons, defensive, engineering and so on. You need to carry cargo from start to finish, while evading asteroids pirates and other rival runners (unlocking new upgrades along the way).

It's a lot of fun, the first time I played it was suddenly 4am.

Tower defence game... in space! Faced with a series of missions you have to build and protect your bizarre hexagon ship. Loads of towers along with various upgrades. The only downside is some of the horrible American accents in the voice acting - ouch!

I really enjoyed Space Run! It came out of nowhere, and was a fantastic and unique take on the Tower Defense genre. The constraints the different missions impose on your ship building are varied and make each level a challenge. Because each level is scripted, it means that you can potentially remember the attack patterns of the enemy for each level, making each successive run easier. I don't see this as a downside, but it does limit replayability.

Worth the Movie Money*.

* Movie Money is the amount of time and enjoyment I could get at the movies for the same amount of money I paid for the game. I valuate if a game is worth purchasing based on this metric.

This game provides more of a puzzle challenge than most of the tower defense games that I'm familliar with.  I got about 20 hours of play out of it, and enjoyed every minute.  The game features unlockable upgrades that you earn for completing levels, gradually your selection of towers expands and allows for more finite control over how you solve the puzzles.  Over all it is a great game and I highly recommend it. 9/10

There is a lot to like about Space Run and few detractors.  Visuals and color pallet are good, the music is enjoyable without being too mellow or overbearing, and the limited voice acting conveys the story appropriately.  Space Run follows the traditional build towers as the level progresses and the warning radar informs you where to best place towers for the upcoming wave.  This game would be much better with more levels available (or a randomizer), but the client differences are the spice of this game.  Most tower defense are the same thing beginning to end, but, in Space Run the client's containers change up the level approach significantly; kudos for making the cargo affect the game.  Big Cargo pods can be located anywhere, Nuclear Star material is best kept safe toward the interior of the ship or you risk massive explosions, VIP Travel cabins are forced to the edge where you lose valuable turret placement options, and the other two clients also throw curves into their missions.  The missions themselves are paced correctly, are not overly long making it easy to replay for five star rankings, and any difficulty can be overcome with a tactical alteration.  I'd like to see some challenge zones with upfront tower building and some configurable ship layouts choices, but as it stands, Space Run is a unique and fun tower defense game.
Really interesting and fun twist on tower defense.  I quite enjoyed this game.
This is the game I needed that I never knew existed.\nTower defense, space ships, freelancing.\nupgrading your ship, economies
Pretty fun Tower Defense with a twist. It gets quite challenging and has a little bit of trial and error. Overall, an enjoyable experience.

Surprisingly fun! I thought I would be turned off immersion-wise by the hex grid ships, but I found myself giving the ships names like corvette and freighters. The placements of weapons are vital (as they take up space and they take up space for the turret), and every building on the limited space on the ship becomes a decisions of pro and cons. Even the objective of the game is a decision (do I forgo weapon and defense for speed and get paid more or do I build defense and attack so I can actually survive the run?).\n\nVery very fun game, and the upgrade system lets you rediscover new uses for weapons after they gain abilities (like a double laser turret becomes a split wide angle cover gun but can't shoot forward)

reviewText:
Space Run in a good game that is a new and fresh view on tower defence. It connects tower defence with space theme.
You build your defences on a ship and protect yourself from space pirates and asteroids. There is a medium pool of different danagers and you need to pick good tools for the job.
You gonna transport five different cargo types, each type is different. Standard cargo is nothing special, nuclear waste explode when destroyed, people want a good view on the action as you shoot down pirates, crystals drain power and AI needs some special stuff.
You need to manage your ship firepower, defences (shields and anti-misiles) and thrust power to make the delivery in time.
It is all quite fun and light, plot is shallow but this is not an RPG game.
Recommended for tower defence fans and space guns fans.

When I first saw this game, it was quite an interesting concept. A combination of a Tower Defense style with some additional strategy added into the mix. I wasn't entirely sure what to expect. I decided to give it a shot and it is certainly worth the price tag. As I am progressing through the levels I find myself needing to go back and redo levels to get better scores and achievements. You have the ability to upgrade your ships abilities and turrets whether it be a more defensive approach or just all out offensive. This is definitely something I can see providing hours and hours of a good time.

The learning curve is quite small. After a couple levels it was easy to catch on and it throws you right into the mix which is very enjoyable rather than a long drawn out tutorial. There is some relatively comedic banter between the android on your ship and others that offer you jobs as well as your characters random one liners. All in all it's a pretty good looking product with a lot of potential for multiple play throughs of each of the levels whether it be making sure you deliver all the cargo without any losses, to trying to get the quickest delivery to get the higher reputation score. The reputation equates to unlocking more levels. More levels mean that you have so many new ship designs which keep you on your toes when it comes to the placement of your turrets.

Thumbs up. I definitely recommend giving this one a shot.

An excellent twist on a beloved genre.  Space Run had me hooked right from the get go with its cheesie one liners and knock off Malcolm Reynolds/Buck Rodgers space captain.

I've been looking at this game for a while with some doubt because the screens and most videos didn't really give me a feel for how it was played or much of any information.

I'll try to provide some help for others in the same situation:
# The game is essentially a tower defense game, mixed up in that the 'tower' you are defending is a moving spacecraft carrying a quantity of cargo which you must physically protect from attacks and safely deliver to the destination. Your spacecraft is made up of a collection of hexagonal tiles, the layout of which differs from mission to mission.

# You will come up against asteroids and pirates in a variety of forms, sizes and quantities including 'boss' type enemies.

# Each mission you begin by placing the single engine and power slots and your assigned quantity of cargo slots across the layout of your ship. You must then start the mission and make use of 'construction points' of which you will be provided some at the beginning and which will slowly regenerate as the missioin progresses.

# You collect more construction points by destroying asteroids, pirates and other cargo ships that you come across, spending these points on slots and special  slots-specific abilities which you unlock as you progress.

# There is strategy in the construction of you ship, using the layout of hexagonal tiles, creating the right mix of offensive, defensive, supportive and engine slots so that you can adequately protect your cargo, survive attacks and go for the speed bonuses on each level - The added constraints of the free space some slots require around the ship and in that some slots require multiple hexes and/or a minimum distance from extra power nodes.

# As you progress, each mission gives you quantities of 'Fame' and 'credits' dependant on your performance. The Fame works like a level cap, with higher levels unlocking new ship slots for you to buy with your credits. You also use credits to upgrade these new slots to add new abilities which you can temporarily switch on during a mission (For example rapid 40 second rapid fire boost for laser turrets). Each slot has three upgrades, the third of which is usually a passive, permanent enhancement of the slot (for example, 30% boost to engine output).

In many ways, this game feels like Space Pirates And Zombies (SPAZ) in art style, combat, upgrades/levelling and to some extent story and humour. There is a smattering of story, but it is essentially pointless.

The tower defense elements are very reminiscent to me of Sanctum in how you are supposed to place, manage and pair them to create the most desireable effect.

There are some complaints that the game ends up requiring too much micro-management, but this feels more me to be a misunderstanding of what the game is: This is not a tower defense game, its more like a strategy defense game. The micro-management is intentional and provides challenge through both the creation of your ship and your use of slots and abilities.

Some of the most fun I've had with the game is micro-managing my turrets so that they create interlocking fields of fire to track a passing ship and gradually shifting the orientation of each turret as the passing ship moves out of the fire arc, slamming the enemy ship with continuous broadsides.

Equally, some of the most tense moments were monitoring areas that were taking a pounding and timing the use of the shield recharge bonus and the Laser turret rapid fire to keep my slots and cargo alive.

I would highly recommend this game.

The ranking system will have you retrying old stages to get a higher score, 10/10.

I like tower defense games a lot in general, and this quickly become one of my favorites. The setting and established objectives in the game add a great new take on the genre, and the entire thing is excellently polished. I do not feel this would help the game as it removes the element of urgency and skill in micro-managing everything in real time. Re-aiming cannons, activating abilities and choosing the placement and type of weapon to place is not particulary difficult until you have to do it in real-time while being attacked by waves of varying enemies

Otherwise the game is fairly good looking. It functions as a 2d game but has a nice compliment of 3d effects and animations. The voice acting and story are .. skippable. Its mostly about the gameplay, which is quite solid.

If you like space genre and tower defense or just fun ( sometimes frustrating :))) game then it is for you. If you dont have hours of free time then this is game for you, each mission takes up to half hour. Also voice is from Starcraft and dialogues are fun and there are many jokes.

One of the best Tower Defence(TD) game I have ever played! Very fast pace, lots of micro, and entremely engaging! You get a set ship layout for each mission which you than build towers and engines on. Engines make it so you get a bonus to how much cargo you kept alive. Towers help you make it to the end alive. You have many upgrades which you unlock throughout the game. Missions can be played more than once and which time you beat it you get money to spend on upgrades. Anyone who likes TDs get this game! Totally worth $20+

This is a verry hard game, but nice to pop in and out. Unlocking new structures is fun but expensive. The story is pretty bland. Basically you are a space trucker and act like you're the ♥♥♥♥ even though the cargo is usualy delivered full of laser holes. Its a backwards tower defence game where you can only place the towers in your base and instead of a path enemies screw you from all directions. You have to decide whether to spend you cash (hexnuts) on defence, offence, or utility. None of your decisions will matter though when asteroids destroy you entirely. You can murder innocent fellow space runners with no attack for money yet somehow even though you are doing the same thing as the pirates no one seems to care. It a really fun and strategic game. A pause button might be nice as the game makes you want to rip your ♥♥♥♥ off at every corner. I give it 89/122 AmeriPoints

The game is a little glitchy, but it's nothing too bad that will mess you up in a fight. If you're into tower defense games, you will like this!

Game has a charm of its own and worth the money :)

When reading reviews prior to playing a game yourself, it can be easy to forget that people are often idiots when it comes to writing reviews.

Quite often, despite 100+ hours of gameplay, you'll have someone trashing out a game for one reason or another - however if they bothered to invest that amount of time, then obviously there's something about the game they quite enjoy.

Space Run is by no means perfect - but what game is? If you enjoy TD games then ~$4 while this is on sale is an absolute steal. You will be surprised by the production value of the game vs. the price tag.

I also recommend Space Run as it attempts to do something different which works.

Many tower defense games have you set up towers and then watch as they do their thing while you have minimal interaction with them. This is quite different - every tower has one or more abilities that can be activated, and you will constantly be triggering abilities and building things during the game. There is no downtime. Personally, I find most TD games a little dull and found the frenetic gameplay of this one to be a refreshing relief. However, people who like more traditional TD games may be turned off by the micromanagement.

Much of the technique involves memorizing the build order -- you play a mission once, lose, then try it again while knowing what will attack when.

Normal mode was fun but a bit easy. Hard mode was poorly balanced - you gain resources so slowly that you need to replay missions a lot to unlock new ones and the grind is not fun.

There is about 20 hours of content here, which will stretch out to about 30 if you want to get a perfect score in each level. It is well worth the purchase price.

It's a bargain price and provides hours of enjoyment. Highly recommened!

An interesting twist on the tower defence genre of games. It may not be very long but it is fun every minute.

It's tower defense with a different facade.

Position your weapons carefully; in addition to choosing the right weapon you have to take firing arcs into consideration.  Turrets cannot be upgraded directly, however they do have special abilities that can be activated at a cost.  Timing those abilities can be a huge difference maker.

Most tower defense games revolve around killing the enemy quickly.  Space Run takes a different approach, it's about arriving at your destination as fast as possible with all of your cargo.  Thus you'll have to balance adding engines and other defenses such as shields and anti-missle turrets in order to get the best possible score.

Your reward for success is reputation and money.  Reputation unlocks missions, weapons and upgrades.  Money is required to purchase those upgrades.  These unlocks include new turret types, faster engines, special abilities you can use in-game or flat passive bonuses that make a certain turret more effective.

One thing that keeps things interesting is varying types of cargo.  Some cargo simply needs to make it there in tact, other cargo introduces new difficulties such as draining nearby modules so they're harder to power, or modules that must be connected by the end of the map (costing you space and resources).   When carrying nuclear warheads you even have the option to use one of them on the enemy, though doing so will cost you as that warhead can't be delivered for obvious reasons.

Overall, it's fun.  My biggest complaint is it's too easy. I've gotten a perfect score the first try on most missions, the remaining ones have been a narrow miss.  There's also little to replay and unfortunately weapons just aren't varied enough.  In general building whatever the best weapon you have access to is the right decision.  Maps also have a tendency to favor sending enemies in from one direction, it makes planning your build up rather easy and predictable.  Additionally, while the game offers something like 30 maps they tend to feel very redundant.

Expect to get about 10 hours out of it, 20 if you're struggling and have to replay a lot.
Fun take on the TD style games.  Would wait for it to go on sale though.

I normally find the tower defense genre to be pretty tired, and as a bonus it doesn't make any sense thematically that armies are attacking my base but only walking down the same road where their previous allies got slaughtered. However I feel that this game's theme (your ship is moving, and it's your ship you're defending) lends itself to more interesting gameplay and more sensible enemy encounters (asteroids, small ships, big ships using different combinations of weapons and loadouts much like yours). As a bonus, they have plenty of evolving and mission specific curveballs to keep the challenge level interesting and get you to think outside of your progressive comfort zone (and, if you're like me, your symmetrical ship design O.C.D.). The dialogue doesn't take itself too seriously, and consequently the humor is pretty high quality as is the voice acting and character design. All around the game just shows a high level of polish in its gameplay design balance, graphical performance, and execution. I highly recommend it! I enjoyed it for a long weekend for about $5, and I found myself compelled to complete all of the acheivements... which is rare for me!

A Tower Attack game?!
The most important thing I want to mention here is, Space Run is a tower defense game. A pretty simple one, mind you. But in depth, it's much more than that.

While the basic of the game consist of building offensive and defensive weapons to keep your ship alive, as well as thrusters to actually move through space, the active part of combat is much more complex than a simple tower defense game. Every structure comes with 3 upgrade slots that can be purchased with credits earned from previous runs. These upgrades mostly consist of 2 active upgrades and one passive upgrade. The active upgrades range from reorienting weapons, over massive single-time attack to quick-repair.

All in all, the tower defense aspect of the game is just one part of it. Using active abilities wiesely, adjsuting to your stubborn cargo and handling all the micro-management, is the really big part of the game. And no, we don't need a pause button or anything, be fast or die, that's it, that's the challenging part of the game. - And really, it's not thaat hard.

Space Run is an interesting and fun mix approach that will kepp you well entertained for ~10h if you want to complete it. With the current number of 30 runs, I have to say, I'm not sure if I would've bought it outside the Steam sale however.

It's so funny and yet challenging, and the voice acting is great also. Lots of replay value since all levels can be completed with different strategies. 10/10 Would recommend.

Space Run is the best and the most innovative tower defense game I've ever played. Superb level design, fun challenges, and great sense of humor is what you are going to get from this joint. My only real critique is that there isn't an easy way to plan out your ship in-game or to re-orient or use abilities right when you need to since it's all in real-time, being able to pause in the way you can in say FTL would be very welcome, but I could see how that might ruin some of the action.

It probably doens't have much replayability since all of the levels have static spawns, but it is a real blast.

Similar breed to the amazing FTL, Space Run is a real-time strategy game where you are supposed to repel fixed enemy attack waves from level to level while delivering different cargo and keeping an eye on your speed and available time. Space Run
Tower defense games aren't my cup of tea , but this one managed to keep me interested and entertained for longer then i expected . Space run spices up the formula quite a lot , you are a space ship that has to deliver something . You have to focus on two things :  the delivery time and protecting your cargo.  You speed your ship up by placing constructions that give you thrust power and you protect your cargo by placing guns , shields ... etc. Space Run fixes almost all the problems i have with the Tower Defense genre , the overwhelming feeling u sometimes get from TD games is gone , the gameplay doesn't feel repetetive and it has a great difficulty curve .

Space run , in my eyes , is an example on how a modern Towerd Defense game should be done . Polished , relaxing  and those cheesy one liners only make the game better .

Space Run is a kind of tower defence game where you also have to factor in a time limit represented by your ship's passage from one space station to another. You transport various types of cargo for corporations and they give you bonuses for delivering their loads on time. Pirates attack your ship from various angles and it sometimes passes through asteroid fields. You can also attack other cargo ships for resources.

Getting safely from A to B is about choosing where to place containers, weapons, shields, generators, and engines. You always have to make allowances for building enough engines to get to your destination ahead of time. The floor-plan of the ship changes with each mission and there are complicating factors such as orientation of weapons and the requirement to provide power to certain modules. Gathering resources makes the difference between being able to repulse attacks and merely limping on to the next encounter. Accruing more resources by destroying other ships and asteroids not only allows you to build more and better modules, it also lets you turn on temporary power-ups.

There is a certain amount of grinding involved to earn better modules and power-ups. Often, necessity takes over from forward planning when it comes to deciding which modules to deploy where. Sometimes, the gameplay can get quite frantic. Massive waves of small fighter craft or heavily armed battleships appear with maybe twenty-five seconds warning, which sounds like a lot, but not when you are in the process of fending off other waves of attackers and you are too low on resources to adequately prepare.

Overall, the game is fun and satisfying. If I could change it in some way, I would give it more levels.

OK... I think I lost track of time playing this game which should be a pretty good sign.

This is a tower defense type of game where you place progressively gun turret, thruster and the such on your ship while trying to deliver precious cargo.  After play phase, you can use earned credit for upgrade and purchase new items (some being unlock based on your reputation... that make the game a little bit more difficult).

The game is well done but there is fews cons in the game:
-  The view of your ship might be too small to see exactly what is going on - No way to zoom in as far as I know
-  Navigation around your ship (to see what is coming to hurt you, or at least trying) is done with the arrow keys... That is darn old way to do it but it is necessary since the WASD keys are use as other shortcut.
- The dialogue can be humoristic but there are too many repeats during the game mode to be enjoyable (like three or four phrases used randomly for key moment).  If you ever played Sacred 1 or 2... you see what I mean.

It is currently bundled on the weekly humble bundle in the pay what you want tier... that means you can get this game for less than a dollar... That is sweet.

I used to play a ton of tower defense games back in the day when they were all made in Flash and playable only in your browser. But after it became overcrowded with generic clones, I thought there was little hope in the genre and left it for dead and moved on with my life. And then came Space Run.

Space Run revived the tower defense love in me, scratching a long-forgotten itch in a really great way. It's intentionally hectic (which is almost akin to playing a game of Starcraft, so if you don't like having to be twitchy with your fingers, this may not be the game for you) with a great dose of strategy in how you want to build and optimise your ship layout.

Decent voice over and plot that gives just enough meaning to doing the runs, which is really all you need without it getting in your gaming.

A solid recommend for tower defense fans who can click fast.

Really looking forward to the sequel Space Run Galaxy!
Space Run is a breath of fresh air for the old TD formula.  It's both great fun and stressful at the same time, but never unfair.  Worth a punt!

Casual tower defence game with an added twist as if you were in space roaming around on a linear path. Writing is quirky and coolish, the game is easy enough to learn without a steep learning curve, you get to put just enough thought into defence design to keep you entertained without feeling like work.

Best damn .33 USD I ever spent.

Thank you Humble Bundle.

-Likeable characters

Loved It

A variant of tower defense where your ship is made of tiles in which you can buy and place a variety of offensive, defensive, and utility structures. Story is minimal and is just something to string together the scenarios but there's enough flavor, humor, and characters with personality (although one-dimensional/no development) that it strings it together well enough for me.

You need to balance your combat structures (that destroy things to gain more money and let you survive to the end) with engine structures (that are necessary for speed bonuses). You unlock new structures by spending points you gain by completing mission objectives. You'll have to grind a little but it isn't so bad if you like to spend time repeating missions to try and get a 5-star rank. However, sometimes it's better to just come back later when you've unlocked the better (although more expensive to place) structures.

There are four types of scenarios, each with unique structures you're forced to place onto the ship that waste space and sometimes have additional negative effects.

It feels like scenarios aren't randomly generated. There are set tiles and seemingly set enemy spawns and patterns. It's pretty nice from a puzzle/high-score aspect because you can figure out and optimize the best build order. I'm pretty surprised that there is no score attack mode/leaderboards because it feels like it would fit well. However, not having randomly generated missions also means that anyone who really likes it will run out of 'fresh' content.

I would have liked to be able to switch difficulty (rather than be locked into one difficulty the whole time). Or at least be able to have all difficulties on the same profile so you can easily switch between difficulties (and progress is separate for each difficulty). As it is you'd have to go back to the main menu to switch profiles for a different difficulty.

Worth a look for people who enjoy tower defense and would like something with a little spin on it.

Wow. So, um... just wow. This was pure gaming bliss! It's a tower defense game with a twist, not triple A by any means (nevertheless incredibly polished). But, somehow... everything was just perfect for me, for my tastes (including the sci-fi feel). This is a literal, hands down 10/10 in my book. It's clear that I won't be able to write an objective review without gushing so I won't even try to continue. Recommended for everyone.

This is a great game.\nI've finished it three times by now on 2 difficultys and it never was the least bit boring or repetitive to me. The game just feels right, the general idea, the mechanics, the balancing, the different abilities, the difficulty, the length of the missions, the graphics, just everything. Even the dialogue is entertaining at times (I didn't think it would be!).\nI can recommend this game to players who like: space games, strategy games, tower defences or even as kind of a time management game, as Space Run combines them all into something great.
this is a fun little game keeps me entertaind but can get hard quick but all in all a fun game. get it when on sale.

Space Run is a twist on tower defense where you protect your ship from all angles while traveling through space. There are lots of weapons and upgrades and many levels require a different strategy. The story is a bit clique, but for a tower defense game to have story at all is nice. The game is fairly long, but each level only takes about 10 minutes. Space Run is definitely worth a buy if you are fan of the genre or want to kill some space pirates in your free time.
Great game! Would not vaycation on these ships

Pretty good game, for a tower defense. Innovative, too.

I recommend it if you're sick and tired of the same old TD playstyle and want something brand new and unique - and if you want to spend a lot of time getting good at micro.

Space Run is utterly frantic at times, and I love that.

A fresh twist on tower defense. The mechanics are easy to learn and the missions get more complicated as the game progresses. You will have to replay previous missions to get enough credits to unlock the more impressive equipment, this is by design and the missions are generally balanced between challenge and fun so it's not really a grind. There is also a difficulty setting, but this can only be set at the creation of a player profile (so you can't easily retry a mission on a harder/easier setting). Overall a good game and a must-have for tower defense fans.\n
Dialogue is kind of cheesy, game is a bit too easy, not really much replayability but all in all it was a good pick up.
Excellent game, definately worth the money. 10/10 : )
